description.text:
This 3D printed Power screwdriver is an quick demonstration of what 3D printing can achieve.

The complete outer shell of power screw driver is 3D printed except for internal electronics .Electronics is extracted from off the shelf power screw driver and assembled into 3D printed shell.

You can view the working using the link below https://youtu.be/blEDwpC6Fbk

Print the downloaded STL file's at 100 micron resolution.
Use pillar structure as support making it easy to post process.

Not a copy of but inspired by parallelgoods' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:903411 self-watering planter, I recreated the idea utilizing a wide mouth mason jar. This is the wide mouth, and won't fit into smaller mouth jars (Diameter is 3.25 inches)

Features small holes to keep roots moistened and half the printing material due to the utilization of the mason jar, or other cup with similar diameter. There is an arched off section which is used to rewater without having to remove the entire structure- there is a small hole to allow the water to drain into the mason jar from this port as well (pictured in the shot of just the device).

Design prints upside down (3.25" side down) to eliminate need for supports.

This is printed on FlashForge Creator Pro with rafts, 200 micron and 15% infill.

Should print easily

Fits great!

title: Solidoodle Workbench/Workbench Apprentice Auto Bed Level Arm

description.text: This is the arm that holds the endstop that probes the bed for the auto level function. A few people on the Solidoodle forum had them break and the design seemed simple enough to re-create. Designed in SketchUp. You might need to compress the arms to slide it in to the mount, but it will snap into place after that.
I printed at the imperial equivalent of .2mm with 2 perimeters and 25% infill on a Solidoodle Workbench. 3 solid top and bottom layers. Use the intended screws to thread into the plastic.

description.text:
Show your Mississippi State pride with this cool desk curio! The logo and stand are designed to fit well together and invite everyone to shout--"We've got some dawgs up in here!"

I designed this in tinkercad.

1. Print both parts: logo and football.
  2. Prop the bottom of the ends of the "M" in the logo into the two angled notches in the gaps where the white bands usually go on a football.
  3. Sit back and hum "Hail State" or ring a freakin' cowbell. Either way works.

comments.text: Before I waste a bunch of time and filament, did you print this with a raft or brim? Just trying to imagine how you removed this from the bed without F'ing it all up. There's a lot of delicate parts there. I typically heat my bed to 90C with PLA and then am able to remove without too much trouble.
comments.author: nickmv

comments.text: I started printing this and everything was golden until I realized, the logo part was way to big for the Football stand... I had to scale it down from 1 to .80 in ReplicatorG. Just a heads up for anyone using a makerbot replicator... Check the logo before you print! lol
comments.author: SinfulSteampunk

comments.text: SS, so the distance from the edge of the "M" to the other edge was greater than the space in between the ends of the football?  Or was the "M" just too thick for the angled gaps?  There might be something to the program used to slice it for your printer.  Interesting!  This is my first uploaded print for TV.  I'm not sure about how designs might work from Tinkercad to ReplicatorG, Cura, etc.  Sorry about that!  Glad you could fix it and use it!  GO DAWGS!  We sorta beat Southern Miss.  Bring on LSU!
comments.author: SinfulSteampunk

comments.text: Yes, that's what I mean haha! The "M" was too wide to fit inside the football... And you're absolutely right, possibly, something to do with RepG during the import. I hadn't sliced it yet when I realized it 'looked' too big, but the other printer had already started printing the football when I measured it. The "M" was HUGE compared to the space allotted in the football. But as you said, it was probably the way RepG handled it. Either way, just wanted everyone to make sure to pay attention to that part of it. Especially us older Makerbot guys. And yea, SMTTT, riiiight... C'mon LSU, you guys might wanna pack up your A Game! haha
comments.author: 3nails4holes

comments.text: You're welcome!  I thought if there's nothing on here, I might as well make some. Hopefully will make more. Go dawgs!

title: Improved One-piece Capo
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
More stylish! More functional! More printable! This is an improved version of my earlier guitar capo (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:698317) that includes a number of improvements:

  • Rubber in the presser bar frets the strings with no buzzing and with less force. (I've also included a version that does not require the rubber piece.)
  • Re-contoured spring section distributes the strain more evenly to prevent breaking.
  • More predictable slicing with specific slicing parameters.
  • Positive stop at the handle prevents accidental breakage.
  • I've added a wide version better for fatter-necked acoustic guitars

If you Liked my original capo, Like this one even more!

Update: I've added versions that don't need the rubber o-ring piece (use the *_no_oring.stl versions of the files), although the versions with the o-rings work more reliably.

Update: I've added a wide version (icapo_wide.stl) which works better for fatter-necked acoustic guitars. Use the standard version (icapo.stl) for electric or thinner-necked acoustic guitars

Follow these instructions exactly for the best results:
Material: PLA
Layer thickness: 0.2mm
No. shells/perimeters: 5
Perimeter line thickness: 0.45mm (exactly)
Infill (rectilinear): 35%

This prints with a build-in channel for an o-ring bumper. The channel has a thin, integral support which peels away easily after printing. You will also need a ~2" length of 3/16" thick o-ring that can either be cut from standard o-ring (http://www.amazon.com/O-Ring-330-BN65-Nitrile-Pack/dp/B000RAI6K4) or can be cut from o-ring cord. Cut a section of o-ring 2.05" long and press into the channel on the presser bar. It's also a good idea to put a small piece of electrical tape or felt on the bottom side of the clamp to protect your guitar neck.

comments.text:
I made the previous one, and it broke, but would like to try again with your exact instructions.
Only, I don't understand how the perimeter line thickness can be 0.45mm if you are making 5 shells? That comes out to 0.09mm/shell- do you set the extrusion width to less than half of the layer height?
comments.author: stemcell

comments.text: I think this is a terminology problem.  By perimeter line thickness, I mean the same thing as the extrusion width.  (Different slicers use different terminology.)  An extrusion width of 0.45mm, times 5 shells equals a total shell thickness of 2.25mm.  This will ensure that that the spring section of the capo is printed solid with no gaps or infill.

Safety Item: Push fit 3D printed soldering iron holder top.

For soldering stands which do not come with a plastic top. Or change for custom colors.

1. Print.
  2. Push1. fit install.
  3. Use.

Without this top the soldeing iron stand is a safety hazard.
My stand did not come with this accessory and it allowed the iron to sit too loose in the holder. Several times the hot iron had been easily pulled out of the holder when I hooked the cord by accident. During my iron falling accidents the falling iron caused anxious moments when I began trying to capture the iron before it bounced on the floor or burned a hole in my crotch.

Inspired by MakerBot's "Zee Blank", I decided to create my own "Blank", but with a slight twist

I have made "The Blanks", a delightful couple of his 'n' hers characters, ready to modify, mash-up and make unique.

The head, body and feet all print as individual parts, making customizing them easy.

Please share your creations with me on Twitter (@deanpunchard) or on Instagram (@punch_ard_digital).

Thanks,
Dean!

These characters started off as quick doodle while sat in my car waiting for a meeting. I then jumped into 3Ds Max, created the characters, and spent several hours itterating the design, and ensuring the various parts fitted together perfectly once printed.

title: Extra Clearance + Spring Tension Base Piece

description.text:
2 improvements:

1) I changed the position of the spring bump up 2mm to increase spring tension when using the springs from the standard makerbot replicator 2 upgrade kit available from makerbot.

2) I had trouble getting proper clearance between this drive block and the base piece and my wires running to my nozzle heaters. I shorted the block 2.5mm on the underside and have had good results. Thought I'd share for those having a similar problem.

Update: Added .STP files for original piece (recreated) that does have the additional spring tension update, but not the shortened base. Also added .STP for the new version.

title: Bowden extruder - pneufit adapter backlash / oozing reduction ring

description.text: In my Printrbot jr. Bowden setup (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:90335) I used pneufit adapters to connect the PFTE cable. However, I noticed that especially during higher extrusion speeds, the pneufit adapters extend (see pictures). Increasing the effective cable length a few mm's, which causes backlash / oozing. This ring pre-tensions the pneufit adapter reducing the extrusion backlash / oozing effects.

description.text:
Update 04.09.2015

Added the fan turbine holder. This gives a mighty blow in the South (if you know what I mean).

The title sounds great, always wanted to announce something simple with a bang.

First of all:

You loose your warranty using this connector (what warranty, the FabTotum Support is crap anyway; buahuahuahua) - I am NOT responsible if you kill your FabTotum (or yourself due to the open electronic parts).

Second:

I wonder why no one really came up with this connector. The FabTotum printer is a real pain itA. Everything is covered. I had a major clogging which was not solvable from the outside (as some cool dude from support suggested). Anyway, I had to heat up my hotend while the cover was gone. Therefore I fired up my RepRap Ormerod 2, printed this part and succeded.

With the new connector all the connectivity issues where gone as well.

Printing is also no problem (but be careful because there is no cooling). Even better than with the plastic cover.

I will work on a solution to connect the turbine fan. I will update this version soon.

Printed with 0.2mm PLA and 25% infill at moderate speed
(be aware that this should be a precision part).

Then I used the two M2.5 screws from the original head to mount it. Be aware that it is a real tight fit. Do not tighten the screws like mad - You need to play with the two screws:

-> Fit it onto the printer and look how the connectors are aligned. Then you can push or pull the connectors to the right or left by loosing or tightening the two screws.

3D Printable module units for building modular robots.- They are very useful for 1D-topology modular robots like caterpillars or snakes, capable of moving along a line (1D) or on a plane (2D). REPYZ modules are an evolution of the REPY modules There are two flavors. The standard REPYZ and the PRO, which includes an 608 bearing for making the movements more smooth More information

• github: https://github.com/Obijuan/REPYZ
  • REPYZ wiki page (in spanish): http://www.iearobotics.com/wiki/index.php?title=M%C3%B3dulos_REPYZ
    • Pictures

• G+ album: https://plus.google.com/u/0/photos/109138697406392447933/albums/5878857037837654529
    • Credits

• David Estevez: Is the author of the Repy v2. Repyz were inspired in Repy v2: http://www.dsquaredrobotics.com/wiki/index.php?title=REPY-2.0

  • Andres Prieto-Moreno. Is the author of the MY1 modules, in which the repyz are also inspired. He also suggested me the idea of including a lower servo cover with ears for the servos. Because of these ears, the body of the module has been dramatically simplified.

  • Gocha is the cat of Carlos Garcia Saura. It is the one that appears on the REPYZ logo
Bill of materials:

• The 3 printed parts: body, head and servo lower cover (There are two differents heads, one for the standard and the other for the PRO)
  • Servo Futaba 3003
  • 1 M8 washer
  • 1 608 bearing (optional, only for the pro version)
  • 4 M3 nuts
  • 4 M3x10mm bolts
  • 2 M2x12mm bolts (provided with the servo)
    • Assembly process: https://plus.google.com/u/0/photos/109138697406392447933/albums/5884847018420290209

title: Rocket for Playmobil Air Booster Rocket Launcher

description.text:
The original one is still ok (only one time glued) but the printed one is more aerodynamic and can fly higher.

Be warned that the tip of the rocket can cause some pain or even damage light things, the rocket is light but is quite fast!

In the blend file there is also a version with non slanted wings, flies maybe even higher but maybe not as that stable.

This is the launcher

It should also fit on the hand launcer they sell.

Much fun for father and son.

The modell has some (cosmetic) issues but prints fine.

One perimeter, NO infill (weight!), detect thin walls, two bottom layers filled, no top layers filled in Slic3r 1.2.9. The slicer complained about "some" errors but I did not care :-)

Printed in PLA. Better first print only a part so you can check if the inner tube fits good on the launcher!

The rippling on the top inner tube is there for a reason, makes the head more rigid and easier to fill the top.

title: Modified Top Brackets for Ultimaker 2 Aluminum Extrusion 3D printer

description.text:
Redid the top Brackets in order to use M3 8mm Hexagon socket head cab screws instead of the Counter-sunk screws originally needed.

The "Shallow" one is the final version and indicates the m3 Hexagon socket heads are totally flush with the top of the bracket, when tightened down.
Same goes for the M5 version.

Why the change:
I bought the 10mm m3 "flat head" screws from the BOM, but they simply weren't long enough and I couldn't find any just a tad longer.
I believe jasonatepaint changed his models a bit, or maybe the BOM.

I recommend printing these with 100% infill as you really want your corners being totally rigid, and you also do not want your screws to sink in (more than they absoluely need to), when tighening them.

I printed with 0.2 layer height and 100% infill.

Print it with the guides facing upwards.

description.text:
This is a quick release nut that I designed for use with my 3D printer spool holder. By depressing the two buttons you can quickly slide the nut to a position along an M8 threaded rod. Then release the buttons and tighten the nut to preference. My application does not call for significant retention force so I have simply printed the threads into the parts. Alternately, I have included a couple of prototype solutions that ought to be more robust. The first is simply to cut a nut in half and insert the halves into the slides and the second uses a couple of small diameter rods as threads.

I am using Slic3r to generate G-code.
SketchUp files are included.
2016-01-24 Update: Cleaned up Sketchup file.

title: HMD-X for the LG G3 & Samsung Galaxy S6

description.text:
Update 10.01.2016:

Compatibility to the S6 (maybe also edge - not testet!) & Google Cardboard Profiles - see the new files :)

Since the mobile phones come a 2K resolution display its very capable of creating a immerse VR experience. All we needed was a suitable head mount with great lenses. So we created a HMD based on the design of the Oculus Rift DK1 - thanks for the great work guys!

All you need are some straps and the lenses - grab two if those here:

http://www.ebay.com/itm/5x-pocket-loupe-magnifier-with-Aspheric-Lens/381581005853

There a three types of holders included - just try which one suits you the best or modify them the way you need it.

With the usage of the "X"-holder its possible to access all the connectors on the phone, keep it kind of cool and even use argmented reality applications.

We gave our best to create the most immerse experience for you to make the time more joyful till the oculus hits the world but we are sure that this thing can be even better! So please mod it / use it / print it the way you like it.

Special thanks to my co-creator SilentBob, to the people of Oculus and the community that made all that possible!

We suggest taping the phone specific "fix"-template to the middle part, taping some foam like material on the middle of the "X" to hold the phone in place and put also tape some skin-friendly soft material on the inner side thats pressed on your head.

comments.text: whats the size of lens? can fit some 25mm?? awesome work!!
comments.author: skeirock

comments.text: The diameter of the lense is 5cm. A smaller lens wontdo the work due to the much smaller FOV. I recommend you to get the lenses I mentioned in the details. Glad you like the idea!
comments.author: skeirock

comments.text: Hi there! what do you think of these lenses? http://www.ebay.com/itm/Emergency-Survival-2-Folding-Pocket-Magnifier-Glass-Lens-5x-FIRE-STARTER-EDC-/182232757781?hash=item2a6deb3615:g:ZFkAAOSwAKxWYyDF

comments.text: Hi pablocho! We always simply tried out lenses but imho you cant expect good quality for that price. In case that the lenses have a different size you have to modify the lense holders.

comments.text: Definitely one of the more detailed designs I've printed out of my printer. Looks cool, but I have two questions:
comments.author: sabretoothed

comments.text: The mechanical parts, especially the ones that are movable, are not altered and originally created by the people of Oculus. We also realized that it's a little bit hard to put them together but we decided, due to the time we already invested in modifying the design, that we dont touch them so its up to your printing and assembling-skills to put the HMD togehter :)
comments.author: sabretoothed

comments.text: Thanks, that helps. I was wondering what the design was based upon so I could take the easy way out without having to design something. But, all good - I'll see what I can figure out with my smaller lenses! Thanks.
comments.author: blue25i

comments.text: You severely restricted the view. :(  why would you design it like this? Are you new to VR or something?
comments.author: DevWolf

comments.text: Can you describe in detail what you mean with "restricted view"?
comments.author: DevWolf

comments.text: Printing it right now, how is it with the lg g3? Do you see the edges of the screen with these lenses?
You >slightly< see the edges of the screen but at least for me it was no problem. Most of the google cardboard apps use faded edges so you wont see the edges. Have fun with your HMD-X :)
How do you think this would work with a Nexus 5? It has a 5" screen and a resolution of 1920x1080. Would your HMD design need to be modified?
comments.author: andyosier

comments.text: It would work for sure BUT 5" is really the minimum. You will clearly the edges of the screen because the magnification of the lenses is only about 3 times. Additionally 1080p will really hurt your eyes when its beeing magnified. And I'm sure you need a new adapter-plate for the Nexus (I've not compared the dimensions of the G3 and the S6 in comparision to the N5 - maybe a already existing plate will fit).
comments.author: andyosier

comments.text: Do you know if I can use my olds google cardboards parts ( the v1 lenses ) with this hmd ?  I just broke my cardboard and I decided that I want a more robust an optimized headmount for my lg g3. Thanks for the project by the way :)
comments.author: Nalf3in

comments.text: Hey Nalf3in! The lenses from your old cardboard are way to small! They will not fit in the lens holder of this HMD and they provide a very small field of view. Also the optics are very bad. I really would suggest investing in the lenses I mentioned in the description or at least in equal ones. Have fun in the world of VR :)
comments.author: Nalf3in

comments.text: I bought the lens that you link to in the description on here. Do I have to remove the black plastic ring from around the lens to fit? If so what lens side should I print out for them to fit? I'm not sure what the 8k means. Thanks for the help.
comments.author: Theonlyjames

comments.text: Hey James! Im glad you wanna build your own HMD-X - you wont regret it! :) You are right - you have to remove the black plastic ring in order to get the lenses in the hmd. We provided three sizes for the lens-holder (K should be suitable for nearsighted people, N for people without glasses and W for farsighted people). But whats the best for you depends on with what holder you feel most comfortable. I would suggest starting with the LensK and if its uncomfortable, try the N. Good luck :)
comments.author: Theonlyjames

comments.text: Awesome! Thanks for the quick reply. I printed out N and they are rendering awesome performance and perfectly snapped into place! I'm using a cubify cubepro printing in ABS. The mechanical parts are not printing perfectly and is not the fault of the drawings is the printers subpar performance. Printing out the mechanical parts to adjust the distance of the phone is proving not to be likely. I know I could grab a couple nuts and bolts and just drill through and slowly adjust, and I'm fine with that. The only problem that arises is that light gets in between the HMD-X_Back.vmf and HMD-X_Middle.vmf. Do you have a work around for this? If not no worries. What you have provided is seriously awesome! Oh also, what do you use to control the phone when its mounted in the headset? Thanks again!
comments.author: blue25i

comments.text: Hey James! :) Yes, I also had problems printing and assembling the mechanical parts but, to be honest, I dont wanted to touch these because the whole thing was work enough and assembling them "the best they can be" works for me. Its crazy that light comes in between the middle and the back part. On my print I cant see any problems, sorry! Since the HMD has no magnetic cardboard-trigger you have to use software thats "triggerable" by looking at a button or thats controllable with a gamepad or something. Some time ago I found the software "TaoVisor 3D App Launcher" - its totally suitable as a vr center. You can switch back from any app just by tilting your head. Hope that helps a little bit :)
comments.author: Theonlyjames

comments.text: Awesome! Thanks again for the info so quickly. I'll try hacking some sort of controller.
comments.author: blue25i

comments.text:
I just started to print it I want to know who buy lenses from my eye care professional . you have some data that I report ? I do not want to wait for the delivery ... I live in Italy lenses there WOULD well a month to arrive ...
Thanks a lot for the project . :)
comments.author: Ricky88

comments.text: Hey Ricky! Great that you give the HMD a try! I'm sorry but I cant provide you more informations about the lenses. We tried alot of types and had the results using these but we also know only whats been written by the seller. Maybe you can try some other lenses with similar specifications (2” diameter, 5x power apheric) that you can get faster. If you have more questions dont hesitate to contact us :)

I made this printer, but I broke my nerves with dual 3D printing and at the end it was reworked to single extruder printer. 400W Fortron PC ATX PSU was used.
It was with 2 homemade 0,4 nozzle hotends( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:955315 ) - 70 mm offset, bowden type extruders.
Electronics - Mega2560 + RAMPs 1,4 + Full_Graphic_Smart_LCD_Controller + 6 NEMA 17 motors. Malrin Fimware.
Achieved 0% backlash effect with this type of Z axis + 10 mm tr3 trapezoidal rods.
Working area was:
1/ As dual extruder printer with 210x200x4mm glass- XYZ - 210/190/300 mm;
2/ As single extruder printer with 400x200x4mm glass - XYZ - 398/190/300 mm for PLA prints and 210/190/300 mm for ABS ones.
Manual control for 40 mm fans for hotends/always ON by default/ and manual control for 30 mm fan ducts with potentiometer for each hotend.

Sourse files (for laser cutting and references) uploaded for AutoCad 2010 or higher version.

You may use this ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:974558 )heatbed version, it should be better.

Use my (bowden version) extruder - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:662780 with mine or fishbone gears or any 1 bowden type extruder with 50 mm offset for mounting holes.

May use my LCD case - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:743724
or any 1 for Full_Graphic_Smart_LCD_Controller and drill 2 holes with 50 mm offset in the back of the case.

Clamp for e3d type hotends also uploaded - You have to rework 30 mm fanduct.

Frame sides are identical so You can choose left or right for electronics, LCD, potentiometers and PSU/ spools and extruders.

The printer is for 10 mm TR3 trapezoidal rods and for this - http://www.technobg.com/uploads/com_article/gallery/thumbs/256x256_a244218b8c02e17641cfef12d9409c1ebf5d9142.jpg type of round TR3 10 mm (D x L) 22 x 15 (mm) nut, that is 3 mm cut from otside diameter!!! Use the same ones or a lot of rework is needed!

All parts for lasercutting can be made from 8 mm plexiglass instead of MDF, but the prices...:
MDF 8 mm ~3,5-4 € for m2 ;
Plexiglass 8 mm ~40-50 € for m2.
Also you have to use super glue, special glue for plexiglass, xylene or chloroform (you have to pay attention for last 2) to assemble the parts.

More photos here - http://www.trendi3dprojects.net/X2.html

If I am missing something - post a comment.

Lift to change spool just like a Dunny Roll holder (Aussie term for toilet roll holder). No more flexing, no more breaking. The original bracket I had split due to flexing back and forth trying to get end cap off, it was a cantilevered design.   
The plate is for screws or rivets, but you might not need it for your setup. I used one plate on back of my display case, and one on the bracket for a screw to bite into. I had a longer screw which I didn't want to protrude quite so much. Holes line up with a slot in my case.  
Feel free to modify as you wish, just add it as a derrivative.

Quick change spool holder. Use a piece of electical conduit, or pipe (~27mm OD). Printed with 40% infill on left and right brackets.
100% infill on plate. No raft or support required. Printed mine with a raft by mistake.

title: Z limit switch holder (M505 Prusa i3 variant)

description.text:
This is a replacement Z limit switch holder for the M505-B. The thicker block replaces the front switch holder which was previously too thin to accurately activate the switch when the carriage came down.

The back piece (the thinner one) is designed thinner to save plastic and prevent replacement of bolts. Also includes recesses for captive M3 nuts (I used some spares from the kit, your's may not be exactly the same size). They do need the application of a little force to fit, but just means they're not going to fall out when you undo bolts.

Please comment if you have any questions or comments. I will try and get back to you as soon as possible.

You have now made perfect threads.
I have made the center part in two different lenghts , one is 5mm longer so you can try alternative depths.

author: sallye6

title: MakerGear M2 Z-axis Home Switch spacer to prevent drift of Z-home

description.text:
I noticed that my Z-axis was wandering a bit after 5 or 10 prints. The distance between the nozzle and the bed was closing-up. This would lead to tears in my tape or vinyl. After investigating a little, I discovered that every time the Z-axis homed, the switch was moving ever so slightly up the linear rail from being bumped during the homing process. I tightened the screws some more, but it still tended to drift, so I made this. Loosen the screws that hold the Z-home switch, slide it down a little. Clip this thing above it. Slide the switch up until it bottoms out against the spacer, then tighten the screws and readjust your Z-axis home for probably the last time ever.
NOTE: This is for MakerGear M2 printers with the V3b extruder. The newer V4 equipped printers have a new home switch design which solves this problem in a similar way.

comments.text: Yes, MakerGear has just started shipping the M2 with the V4 extruder which uses a different home-switch mount.  This part is meant to address the drift issue with the previous version (V3b).  Cheers, c

author: Protonik

description.text: Batman inspired book keep- a closer strap to keep books closed and paper safe.

Since my accident forced me to retire on disability. I ,now, have returned to sketching ( when I am up to it) and writing to kill time.
So, I keep sketch books and note books on hand. I always had an issue with pages , loose notes and sketches falling out since grade school.
I used to use heavy rubber-bands but they ruin the books by pulling in to tight and cutting into the pages and covers. Heavy womens hair scrunchies quickly loose their shape. I came up with this , after seeing a researchers note book with a permanently attached elastic band.
I got the heavy wide elastic at a craft store and measured to fit my books and etablets. used SVG INKSCAPE to due the graphic. Tinkercad to do the stl for print, and Mona ( a Makerbot 2x named for sounds it makes , when she is in use) to print. It was white as you see, so I painted it black( next time i will print it in black)
The symbol is Jerry Robinson's take on the classic 1940's -1950's Batman Chest emblem.
BatFact - Batman's costume the cape, cowl and accessories were never intended to be blue, Bob Kane wanted it to be printed as Black and dark Gray- Due to the limitations of printing at the time. Blue was used as the color. Kane was quoted as blue was used since Black fabric would have a blue highlight in the bright light and printing in all black would over saturate the printing paper in use at the time and make it look like it was water logged.
Thom aka The Technognome
I submit this as open from fan to fan, not for profit reproduction.
All rights to DC Comics Inc, Warner Brothers and respective artists.

Used for letting a Craftsman saw's (maybe others) on/off switch function. Without a key, the machine won't turn on.

My dad broke/lost all of his except one, so this was designed after that one. There are three types.
One with just the legs, which would probably never be able to be removed without some significant work.
Another with a flat top. This one prints out looking nicer, but one side does stick out of the hole it goes into, since it isn't slanted to match the curve of the piece.
The last one has a slanted top, to more closely match the original piece, and it is really only missing the curve on the sides. This one prints pretty well with no support if you have it layed out with the top flat on the print surface and the legs at an angle. If you don't mind a little remnants of the supports on the top, you can print it with the legs straight up.
Edit (2015-12-11): Added files to print the cap and legs separately. They can be glued together afterward, but this seems to increase the strength of the legs.

Such a small thing can improve your printing quality , or even transform a not useable assembly into a fully workin printer !

If you follow the cobblebot's how to , you will either have wobbly idlers or fully fixed ones because of the bearings sleeves end outer rings being pressed against the mouning plate.

You will need one big and two smalls shims for each idler, fit the big one in the big bearing and put the screw in it then a small bearing and a small shim and do it a second time. You shall have no bearing touching any other (or slightly, if it spins freely when tight , then it's a succes) .

You may have to do some filing/scaling , such small object can be hard to print with acuracy.

For owner of the cobblebot only : If your steppers keep skipping , try putting a lot of lube on the belt and , if it still doesent work, increasing the current limitation of the drivers (blow on them with a fan if possible) , this upgrade shoul remove your issue.

Its an GoPro Clip with the possibility to mount it on a 7mm or less rod.
You'll need just 4 pieces of M3 Screws to fix it where ever you like to.

Update, should now fit 100%.

title: Bed OF Nails dot
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I'm not crazy!
This plastic dot can be used like a mini bed of nails, to increase blood flow and relax muscles. Print a number of these dots and stand on them to help relax your feet, or glue/sew them onto a cushion or mat, to make a bed of nails big enough to lay on. I can't guarantee the medical benefits, but it can help improve circulation and relax muscles. Edit: I've uploaded a picture of a chair cushion from a cheapie shop, covered in spikes. Ideal for use on feet, or on your seat while at the computer. The $6 cushion took about 60 dots (at about $0.10 each for material) = total materials cost of $12.

Note: the spikes shouldn't be sharp enough to puncture skin, given the roughness of typical printing methods, but please be careful to ensure that you won't hurt yourself (I take no responsibility)

  • Select the style of dot that you want to print. the "deb_of_nails dot" has a larger quantity of spikes, so may be better if you haven't used them before. Otherwise, try the BIG (same size dot, but bigger spikes)

  • select your method of use, then figure out how many you will need to cover the space you desire (either enough to stand on, or enough to cover the mat that you are covering, arranging them with about 5mm gap between adjacent dots)

  • print the dots

  • if sticking the dots to a mat or cushion, they may be sewn on (using the small holes arranged on them), or glued on (apply the glue to the back of the dot, letting it flow into the expanding grooves on the back surface, then pressing them onto the mat)

  • Stand on the dots to relax your feet, or lay on them, to relax your back.
    • Note: thin-ish cushions or mats work best for making bed-of-nails mats. if the cushion is too soft or thick, you won't get the full effect. if the cushion is too thin (e.g yoga mat) it may feel to hard and spiky to stand on. a cushion about 12-15cm thick seems to work well.
